    Alexandra Lange. Photo: Mark Wickens/Pulitzer.org

    Alexandra Lange, the popular CityLab contributor and widely read critic of design for The New Yorker and other outlets, has won this year's Pulitzer Prize in the Criticism category. 

    Lange, a Yale and NYU alumna whose career began as a staffer for New York magazine in 1994, has been an influential presence in the age of digital media. Recent articles have illuminated topics such as neurodiverse urban design, the sculpture practice of Hugh Hayden, so-called 'Skate Gardens', swingsets, and corporate modernism. She is known as the author of an influential 2022 title looking at the phenomenon of dead malls in America, and was one of nine Harvard GSD Loeb Fellows in the 2014 cycle.

    Reacting to today's announcement via X, both Mark Lamster and Blair Kamin have already shared their considerable excitement. Lange is the first art, architecture, or design critic to win in the category since Christopher Knight in 2020. She joins a cohort of architecture critics Inga Safron, Kamin, and the late Robert Campbell, who have all won the Pulitzer in the last 30 years.
